diagnoses: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome

diagnoses.name: Rocky Mountain spotted fever
diagnoses.description: A tick-borne illness caused by the bacterium Rickettsia rickettsii, characterized by fever, thrombocytosis, erythematous rash often starting at the wrists and ankles then spreading, which may include the palms and soles.

diagnoses.name: Kawasaki disease
diagnoses.description: A condition that causes inflammation in the walls of some blood vessels in the body. It's most common in infants and young children. Symptoms include fever, rash, swelling and redness of the hands and feet, and red eyes.

diagnoses.name: Chikungunya
diagnoses.description: A virus transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes causing fever, severe joint pain, and rash. The rash can be maculopapular and sometimes includes the feet and hands.

diagnoses.name: Dengue fever
diagnoses.description: A mosquito-borne viral illness presenting with high fever, headache, rash, and severe muscle and joint pain. Thrombocytosis occurs late in the disease.

diagnoses.name: Zika virus
diagnoses.description: Another mosquito-borne viral infection leading to fever, rash, joint pain, and conjunctivitis, with maculopapular rash including the hands and feet.

diagnoses.name: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
diagnoses.description: A severe drug reaction affecting the skin and internal organs. Symptoms might include fever, rash, swelling, and elevated white blood cell count including eosinophilia and thrombocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Ehrlichiosis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection transmitted by ticks. Symptoms include fever, muscle aches, and possibly rash. Thrombocytosis could also be present.

diagnoses.name: Scarlet fever
diagnoses.description: A bacterial illness that develops in some people who have strep throat. It's characterized by a bright red rash on the body, fever, and throat pain.

diagnoses.name: Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP)
diagnoses.description: A disease of the skin and other organs that most commonly affects children. Symptoms include rash, joint pain, abdominal pain, and kidney involvement.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatic fever
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that can develop as a complication of inadequately treated strep throat or scarlet fever. Symptoms include fever, joint pain, rash, and inflammation of the heart valves.

Rickettsial diseases (including Rocky Mountain spotted fever)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect multiple systems including the kidneys, skin, heart, lungs, and brain. It can present with fever, delirium, nephritis, pleural effusion, and pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Viral Infection
diagnoses.description: Various viral infections can lead to symptoms such as fever, acute pericarditis, and pleural effusions. Examples include Coxsackievirus and echovirus.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatic Fever
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that can develop as a complication of untreated or poorly treated strep throat or scarlet fever. It can affect the heart, joints, skin, and brain.

diagnoses.name: Infective Endocarditis
diagnoses.description: An infection of the inner lining of the heart chambers and valves. It can cause fever, delirium, and can lead to complications such as pericarditis and pleural effusion.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis (TB)
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It primarily affects the lungs but can also affect other parts of the body, causing fever, pleural effusion, and pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Renal Abscess
diagnoses.description: Localized collections of pus in the kidneys due to a bacterial infection. It can cause fever, delirium, and nephritis.

diagnoses.name: Septicemia
diagnoses.description: Also known as sepsis, it's a potentially life-threatening condition caused by the body's response to an infection. It can lead to fever, delirium, and multiple organ dysfunction.

diagnoses.name: Malignancy
diagnoses.description: Certain cancers can cause symptoms like fever, delirium, nephritis, pleural effusion, and pericarditis due to direct invasion, paraneoplastic syndromes, or metastasis.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that has features of lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis. It can present with fever, nephritis, pericarditis, and pleural effusions.

diagnoses.name: Drug-induced Lupus
diagnoses.description: A lupus-like syndrome triggered by certain prescription drugs. Symptoms can mimic those of systemic lupus erythematosus including fever, pericarditis, and pleural effusions.

diagnoses: Toxic ingestion (including alcohol withdrawal in susceptible individuals)
Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) with CNS involvement
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome

diagnoses.name: Dengue Fever
diagnoses.description: A mosquito-borne viral illness causing high fever, severe headache, pain behind the eyes, joint and muscle pain, and rash.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatic Fever
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection that can follow strep throat and scarlet fever, leading to long-term heart damage if untreated. Symptoms include fever, painful and swollen joints, skin rash, and involuntary muscle movements.

diagnoses.name: Chikungunya
diagnoses.description: A viral disease transmitted to humans by infected mosquitoes. Symptoms include the sudden onset of fever and severe, often debilitating joint pain.

diagnoses.name: Zika Virus
diagnoses.description: A mosquito-borne virus causing mild symptoms in most, including fever, rash, conjunctivitis, and joint pain. However, it is linked to birth defects when pregnant women are infected.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease where the body's immune system attacks its own tissues, causing widespread inflammation and tissue damage in the affected organs. Common symptoms include fatigue, joint pain and swelling, rash, and fever.

diagnoses.name: Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever
diagnoses.description: A bacterial disease spread by ticks causing fever, headache, abdominal pain, vomiting, and muscle pain. A characteristic rash may develop a few days after the fever.

diagnoses.name: Henoch-Schönlein Purpura
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of small blood vessels that causes them to leak, leading to a rash of purplish spots, joint pain, abdominal pain, and kidney issues.

diagnoses.name: Hepatitis B
diagnoses.description: A serious liver infection caused by the hepatitis B virus that's easily preventable by a vaccine. Symptoms can include: fatigue, mild fever, joint pain, rash, and jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes). Chronic infection can lead to liver failure, cancer, or cirrhosis.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium spread by ticks. Early symptoms include fever, headache, fatigue, and a characteristic skin rash called erythema migrans.

diagnoses.name: Rat-Bite Fever
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease that can result from a bite or scratch of a rodent, or the ingestion of food or water contaminated with rat feces. Symptoms include fever, vomiting, joint pain, rash, and muscle pain.

diagnoses: Vasculitis (e.g., Henoch-Schönlein purpura, Granulomatosis with polyangiitis)
Infectious diseases (e.g., Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C, HIV)
Viral Infections (e.g., Dengue Fever, Ebola Virus)

diagnoses.name: Urinary Tract Infection
diagnoses.description: An infection in any part of the urinary system, kidneys, bladder, or urethra.

diagnoses.name: Otitis Externa
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the outer ear and ear canal.

diagnoses.name: Lymphadenitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the lymph nodes typically due to infection.

diagnoses.name: Arteriovenous Malformations
diagnoses.description: An abnormal connection between arteries and veins, bypassing the capillary system.

diagnoses.name: Dysgeusia
diagnoses.description: A distortion of the sense of taste.

diagnoses.name: Ménière's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the inner ear causing vertigo, tinnitus, and hearing loss, sometimes linked with dysgeusia due to its effects on inner ear structures.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A chronic condition that affects how the body processes blood sugar (glucose). It can sometimes cause issues like urinary tract infections due to high blood sugar levels.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An immune system disorder characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth. It has been associated with taste disturbances like dysgeusia.

diagnoses.name: Bell's Palsy
diagnoses.description: A condition that causes sudden, temporary weakness in the facial muscles which can impact taste on the front two-thirds of the tongue.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: A virus that damages the immune system and can cause a variety of symptoms, including lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Infection
reasoning: Hyperthermia often signifies an infection. In conjunction with monocytosis, it suggests a systemic infection.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
reasoning: Dysautonomias and difficulty focusing vision are common in MS. Monocytosis may indicate an inflammatory process, which is consistent with MS.

diagnoses.name: Sjogren's Syndrome
reasoning: Dysautonomias and oral pain (due to dryness) are common. Monocytosis can be a non-specific sign of chronic inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Behcet's Disease
reasoning: Can cause oral pain (mouth ulcers), hyperthermia, and dysautonomias. Vision problems are due to eye inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
reasoning: Often involves dysautonomias and hyperthermia. Monocytosis and vision problems can occur due to granuloma formation in various tissues, including the eyes.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
reasoning: Can present with dysautonomias, hyperthermia, and monocytosis. Oral pain could be due to oral ulcers, and SLE can affect vision.

diagnoses.name: Leukemia
reasoning: Monocytosis is a key feature, especially in chronic myelomonocytic leukemia. Can indirectly lead to hyperthermia, oral issues due to mucositis, and neurologic symptoms affecting vision.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
reasoning: Caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, it can lead to monocytosis, hyperthermia, and oral pain. Neurological manifestations might explain difficulty focusing vision.

diagnoses.name: Giant Cell Arteritis
reasoning: Primarily affects adults over 50. Symptoms can include vision difficulties due to inflammation of blood vessels and systemic symptoms like fever.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
reasoning: HIV infection can cause a wide range of symptoms including monocytosis and oral pain (due to opportunistic infections), along with neurological complications that might affect vision.
Depression is a prominent symptom, potentially indicative of a depressive disorder.
Seizure disorders, particularly those with focal onset, could suggest involvement of structures such as the temporal lobe, which can also impact mood regulation.
Blood pressure lability may signify episodes of significantly high blood pressure, necessitating further investigation for potential end-organ damage.
Given the multi-system involvement (CNS with seizure, potential skin with Otitis Externa, immune with lymphadenitis), SLE could be a unifying diagnosis.
Could account for psychiatric symptoms (depression), cranial nerve involvement (Otitis Externa), and neurological symptoms (seizures).
Certain substances or medications could cause both mood disturbances (such as depression) and fluctuations in blood pressure.
Could explain lymphadenitis and possibly, though less commonly, otitis externa and neurological symptoms.
While less common, ALL could account for generalized symptoms such as lymphadenopathy and neurological symptoms due to CNS involvement.
This rare tumor could cause episodic hypertension (blood pressure lability) along with other symptoms due to excess catecholamine release.
Given the presence of depression, it's also crucial to consider non-epileptic seizures, which are psychological rather than physiological in origin.

diagnoses: Anemia related to chronic kidney disease

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: A disease involving abnormal collections of inflammatory cells that form lumps known as granulomas. The condition can affect the lungs, lymph nodes, eyes, and skin.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: A contagious infection caused by the bacterium Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It primarily affects the lungs but can also affect other parts of the body.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: A tick-borne illness caused by the bacterium Borrelia burgdorferi. It can lead to a wide range of symptoms, including fever, rash, facial paralysis, and arthritis.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) damages the immune system and interferes with the body's ability to fight infections. Without treatment, it can lead to AIDS (acquired immunodeficiency syndrome).

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that causes chronic inflammation of joints. It can also cause inflammation of the tissue around the joints, as well as in other organs in the body.

diagnoses.name: Syphilis
diagnoses.description: A sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum. Its symptoms are very diverse and can affect many organs in the body.

diagnoses.name: Cat Scratch Disease
diagnoses.description: An infection caused by the bacterium Bartonella henselae, usually following a scratch or bite from a cat. Symptoms include fever, fatigue, and swollen lymph nodes.

diagnoses.name: Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of lymphoma, which is a cancer originating from lymphocytes, a type of white blood cells. Symptoms include painless swelling of lymph nodes, fatigue, and fever.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. This interferes with the communication between the brain and the rest of the body.

diagnoses.name: Measles
diagnoses.description: A highly contagious viral infection that affects the respiratory system, immune system and skin. Characterized by fever, cough, rash, and eye irritation.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause a wide range of symptoms, including malabsorption due to gastrointestinal involvement, and neurological symptoms such as word-finding difficulty.

diagnoses.name: Behcet's Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: May present with a variety of symptoms including vascular problems like aneurysms, and mucosal involvement that could explain vaginitis.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.reasoning: Diverse group of disorders that involve inflammation of blood vessels. Can cause aneurysms and various systemic symptoms depending on the vessels involved.

diagnoses.name: Marfan Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: Connective tissue disorder that can lead to aneurysms especially in the aorta and can have systemic effects that could theoretically lead to some of the other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Carcinoid Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: Caused by a type of neuroendocrine tumor that can produce flushing and malabsorption among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Neurofibromatosis
diagnoses.reasoning: Genetic disorder that causes tumors on nerve tissue and can have diverse manifestations including skin changes (possibly contributing to flushing) and neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM)
diagnoses.reasoning: Rare lung disease that primarily affects women, leading to lung cysts and abdominal tumors which could theoretically relate to malabsorption and flushing.

diagnoses.name: Fibromuscular Dysplasia
diagnoses.reasoning: Condition that causes growth of fibrous tissue in the walls of medium-sized arteries and can lead to aneurysms and arterial dissections.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Autoimmune disorder that results in malabsorption due to a reaction to gluten, could be associated with general malaise possibly affecting neuropsychiatric function but less likely to directly cause the other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: Autoimmune disease that primarily affects salivary and lacrimal glands, but could potentially lead to neurological complications and systemic effects that might coincidentally cover a broad symptomatology.

diagnoses: Asthma (with a possible overlap of anxiety and allergy components)
Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) (which can present with post-nasal drip and hypersensitivity reactions)

diagnoses.description: Depression
diagnoses.reasoning: Depression can present with a wide range of symptoms including hypersomnolence, increased appetite, and can indirectly lead to conditions causing physical sensitivities. Psychosomatic manifestations can sometimes include conditions like vulvodynia.

diagnoses.description: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.reasoning: Fibromyalgia is associated with widespread pain and physical sensitivities, including potential vulvodynia. Patients may experience fatigue that can manifest as hypersomnolence and may report an increased appetite as part of their symptomatology.

diagnoses.description: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (CFS) is characterized by significant fatigue that can manifest as hypersomnolence. Patients may experience a range of sensitivities, including to foods, odors, chemicals, or sounds, potentially contributing to bronchitis symptoms due to environmental sensitivities.

diagnoses.description: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.reasoning: Hypothyroidism can lead to symptoms of hypersomnolence and an increased appetite. It can also contribute to a general state of fatigue and sensitivity, possibly aggravating or mimicking conditions like vulvodynia.

diagnoses.description: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.reasoning: PCOS can contribute to a wide range of symptoms including increased appetite. It is also associated with hormonal imbalances that could indirectly contribute to symptoms such as vulvodynia and physical sensitivities.

diagnoses.description: Sleep Apnea
diagnoses.reasoning: Sleep Apnea could be a direct cause for hypersomnolence. While it is primarily a sleep disorder, the resultant poor sleep quality can lead to an increased appetite and general sensitivities due to fatigue.

diagnoses.description: Chronic Pain Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: Chronic pain syndrome can directly contribute to physical sensitivities and may include or exacerbate conditions like vulvodynia. The ongoing pain can impact sleep, leading to hypersomnolence, and affect appetite.

diagnoses.description: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.reasoning: Diabetes Mellitus can manifest with an increased appetite as well as contribute to conditions such as vulvodynia through neuropathy. Poorly managed diabetes can lead to fatigue, contributing to hypersomnolence.

diagnoses.description: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.reasoning: Anxiety can manifest with physical symptoms including hypersomnolence, increased appetite, and various sensitivities due to heightened nervous system activity. It can also exacerbate or contribute to conditions like vulvodynia.

diagnoses.description: Allergic Rhinitis
diagnoses.reasoning: While primarily known as a nasal symptom disorder, allergic rhinitis can contribute to bronchitis symptoms due to post-nasal drip and infection spread. Indirectly, it can affect sleep quality, leading to hypersomnolence, and could exacerbate sensitivities.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that often presents with dry eyes and dry mouth, which could explain the dry eyes and can sometimes be associated with lymphadenopathy. Depression is also commonly reported in Sjögren's Syndrome due to the chronic nature of the condition.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can cause a wide range of symptoms, including leukocytosis, hypersensitivity reactions, depression, and lymphadenopathy. Dry eyes could also be a symptom due to associated Sjögren's syndrome.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that primarily affects joints but can also cause dry eyes (secondary to Sjögren's syndrome), leukocytosis during active inflammation, hypersensitivity reactions, and depression due to chronic pain.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: HIV infection might cause lymphadenopathy, hypersensitivity reactions (e.g., from medications or the virus itself), depression as a result of the chronic illness, and leukocytosis in some stages or presentations.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: A disease involving abnormal collections of inflammatory cells that can form as nodules in multiple organs, causing dry eyes, leukocytosis, hypersensitivity reactions, depression, and lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection that primarily affects the lungs but can spread to lymph nodes (causing lymphadenopathy) and other parts of the body, potentially leading to hypersensitivity reactions, leukocytosis, and depression due to chronic illness.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that begins in the lymphatic system, which can cause lymphadenopathy, leukocytosis, depression, and depending on the type and location, hypersensitivity reactions. Dry eyes could be secondary to systemic effects of the illness or treatments.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition, which might include symptoms like hypersensitivity reactions and depression. Dry eyes and lymphadenopathy can be associated symptoms but are less commonly primary symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Graft-versus-host disease (GVHD)
diagnoses.description: A condition that occurs after an allogeneic tissue transplant, where the donor's immune cells attack the recipient's body tissues, causing symptoms like dry eyes, leukocytosis, hypersensitivity reactions, depression, and lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout your body, leading to symptoms like hypersensitivity reactions, depression, and possibly dry eyes, though leukocytosis and lymphadenopathy could be less directly associated.

diagnoses.name: Hyperimmunoglobulin E Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare immunodeficiency disorder characterized by high levels of serum IgE, eosinophilia, and recurrent skin and lung infections.

diagnoses.name: Common Variable Immunodeficiency
diagnoses.description: An immune system disorder characterized by low levels of several immunoglobulin (antibodies) which leads to increased susceptibility to infections.

diagnoses.name: IgG4-Related Disease
diagnoses.description: A condition that can cause inflammation in any part of the body, typically presenting with elevated levels of IgG4 in the blood.

diagnoses.name: Churg-Strauss Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A disorder marked by blood vessel inflammation, which can restrict blood flow to organs and tissues, often associated with eosinophilia.

diagnoses.name: Hypereosinophilic Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by a persistently elevated eosinophil count in the blood without a known cause, which can affect multiple organs.

diagnoses.name: Selective Immunoglobulin A (IgA) Deficiency
diagnoses.description: This is the most common primary immunodeficiency, characterized by an absence or severely reduced level of IgA antibodies.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.description: A chronic digestive disease where stomach acid or bile irritates the food pipe lining, might be seen with other systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Eosinophilic Esophagitis
diagnoses.description: An allergic/immune condition characterized by eosinophils, a type of white blood cell, building up in the esophagus.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Polyendocrinopathy-Candidiasis-Ectodermal Dystrophy (APECED)
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic disorder characterized by the development of autoimmune disorders affecting endocrine glands, among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease characterized by dry eyes and mouth, but can also cause dysfunction in other organs, including the gastrointestinal system.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones. Symptoms can include xerosis (dry skin), hyperlipidemia (which could manifest as dyslipidemia), and increased susceptibility to infections due to a slower metabolism possibly affecting the immune response. Hearing loss can be associated with long-term untreated hypothyroidism.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A group of diseases that result in too much sugar in the blood (high blood glucose). Diabetes can lead to xerosis as a result of dehydration from increased urination, dyslipidemia particularly in type 2 diabetes, increased susceptibility to infections due to impaired immune response, and hearing loss.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that attacks the glands responsible for keeping the eyes, mouth, and other parts of the body moist and lubricated, leading to xerosis. It's also associated with an increased risk of infections.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human Immunodeficiency Virus/Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome significantly weakens the immune system, making the body more susceptible to infections. Patients may also experience xerosis as part of their symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Uremia
diagnoses.description: A condition associated with the late stages of kidney failure, characterized by high levels of waste products in the blood. Symptoms can include xerosis, dyslipidemia, and an increased risk of infections due to the buildup of toxins affecting various body systems, including the immune system.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Sensory and Autonomic Neuropathy Type 1 (HSAN1)
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic disorder that affects the sensory and autonomic neurons, leading to a loss of sensation and an inability to feel pain or temperature changes, which might indirectly relate to xerosis and increased susceptibility to injuries and infections.

diagnoses.name: Psoriasis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune skin disease that speeds up the life cycle of skin cells, causing them to build up rapidly on the surface of the skin. The extra skin cells form scales and red patches that are itchy and sometimes painful. Psoriasis can lead to xerosis and has been associated with an increased risk of dyslipidemia and other metabolic syndrome components.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Liver Disease/Cirrhosis
diagnoses.description: As liver function declines, a variety of symptoms can appear, including xerosis due to changes in metabolism and nutrient absorption. Dyslipidemia can also occur as the liver plays a key role in lipid metabolism.

diagnoses.name: Atopic Dermatitis
diagnoses.description: A condition that makes your skin red and itchy. It's common in children but can occur at any age. Atopic dermatitis is long lasting (chronic) and tends to flare periodically. It may be accompanied by asthma or hay fever, and can lead to skin infections due to scratching and impaired skin barriers.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: A systemic autoimmune disease that occurs when your body's immune system attacks your own tissues and organs. Symptoms and outcomes can vary widely among individuals but can include skin manifestations such as xerosis and increased susceptibility to infections.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin C Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Vitamin C deficiency can lead to symptoms including gum disease (periodontal disease), easy bruising and bleeding, joint pain, and poor wound healing. Severe prolonged deficiency can cause scurvy, which may present with signs such as anemia, debility, and bone pain (potentially contributing to conditions like osteopenia).

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: Iron deficiency anemia can manifest with presyncope due to decreased oxygen delivery to the brain. Other symptoms can include pale skin, weakness, and, in severe cases, inflamed or sore tongue and gums, contributing to periodontal disease. Chronic blood loss from hemorrhoids can contribute to this condition.

diagnoses.name: Dehydration
diagnoses.description: Dehydration can lead to dry, irritated eyes, and in severe cases, presyncope. Chronic dehydration can contribute to the development of hemorrhoids by leading to constipation and straining during bowel movements.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: Hypothyroidism can indirectly contribute to symptoms such as elevated cholesterol levels, which may predispose individuals to hemorrhoids. It can also cause dry skin and, consequently, irritated eyes. Additionally, it might contribute to osteopenia due to altered metabolism.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: Diabetes can lead to a wide range of complications including gum disease, due to poor blood sugar control, and can contribute to osteopenia through complex metabolic processes. It may also cause general weakness or dizziness associated with presyncope.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin D Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Vital for bone health, a deficiency in Vitamin D can lead to osteopenia and elevated risk of periodontal disease. Indirectly, severe deficiency may also contribute to muscle weakness and fatigue, potentially explaining presyncope.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: Chronic kidney disease can lead to a broad spectrum of metabolic disturbances including electrolyte imbalances causing presyncope, worsened hypertension contributing to hemorrhoidal discomfort, and calcium/phosphorus metabolism affecting bone density leading to osteopenia.

diagnoses.name: Inflammatory Bowel Disease
diagnoses.description: Inflammatory bowel disease can contribute to hemorrhoids due to frequent bowel movements and straining. It can also lead to iron deficiency anemia, which in turn may cause presyncope. Eye irritation can also be a related extraintestinal manifestation.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that primarily causes dryness of the eyes and mouth, it could explain the symptom of irritated eyes. Additionally, the chronic inflammation seen in Sjögren's could contribute to periodontal disease.

diagnoses.name: Plaque Psoriasis
diagnoses.description: Plaque psoriasis is an autoimmune condition that can affect various parts of the body. It can indirectly contribute to periodontal disease due to associated inflammation and might influence the development of comorbidities like osteopenia through systemic inflammatory processes.

diagnoses: Hypertensive heart and chronic kidney disease
Systemic Lupus Erythematosus with renal involvement

diagnoses.name: Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder characterized by inflammation of the blood vessels, which can restrict blood flow to various organs.

diagnoses.name: Churg-Strauss Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disease causing inflammation of blood vessels and can lead to sinus problems and rash.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissue, can cause rash and weight loss.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease affecting multiple organs in the body, primarily the lungs and lymph glands.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout the body, including the skin, causing rashes and other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Mastocytosis
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by an excessive number of mast cells in the body, can lead to skin lesions (urticaria pigmentosa), gastrointestinal symptoms, and mood lability.

diagnoses.name: Rosacea
diagnoses.description: A chronic skin condition that causes redness and visible blood vessels in your face.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and skin rash.

diagnoses.name: Cutaneous T-Cell Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A rare type of cancer that begins in the white blood cells and attacks the skin, causing rash, plaques, and tumors.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human Immunodeficiency Virus weakens a person's immune system by destroying important cells that fight disease and infection.

diagnoses: Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease and Ulcerative colitis)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis)
Constitutional Delay of Growth and Puberty

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Anaphylactic shock due to food allergy
Toxic ingestion (e.g., certain plant toxins, chemicals)
Inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis)
Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) exacerbation with secondary infection
Common Cold Complicated by Acute Gastroenteritis
Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) - for dyspnea
Inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.details: A neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms. It's frequently characterized by intense, debilitating headaches.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.details: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.details: Occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.details: An inflammation of the fluid and membranes (meninges) surrounding your brain and spinal cord.

diagnoses.name: Intracerebral Hemorrhage
diagnoses.details: A type of stroke caused by bleeding within the brain tissue itself – a life-threatening type of stroke.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.details: An inflammation of the brain. Cause is often viral, but it can also be bacterial or due to autoimmune diseases.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.details: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves.

diagnoses.name: Dehydration
diagnoses.details: A severe loss of body fluid can lead to headaches, vomiting, and numbness.

diagnoses.name: Hypoglycemia
diagnoses.details: Low blood sugar can cause a variety of symptoms including headache, vomiting, and numbness.

diagnoses.name: Temporal Arteritis
diagnoses.details: An inflammation of blood vessels, typically in the head, that can cause headache and, in severe cases, can lead to complications such as blindness or stroke.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache that is often accompanied by visual disturbances (aura), sensitivity to light (photophobia), sound (phonophobia), and can include speech disturbances (dysarthria).

diagnoses.name: Migraine without Aura
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms including photophobia, phonophobia, but not typically dysarthria or scintillation.

diagnoses.name: Cluster Headaches
diagnoses.description: Severe unilateral headache that comes in clusters, and might also involve photophobia and phonophobia but less commonly dysarthria or visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Tension-Type Headaches
diagnoses.description: The most common type of headache, which can sometimes feature photophobia and phonophobia but usually lacks the other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, it can present with dysarthria, and less commonly with other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A cerebrovascular accident that can manifest with dysarthria, and in some cases with photophobia, and less commonly with phonophobia.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease of the brain and spinal cord that can cause dysarthria, and in some cases, visual disturbances such as scintillations.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumors
diagnoses.description: Depending on the location and size, a brain tumor can cause a variety of symptoms including dysarthria, photophobia, scintillation, and phonophobia.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the brain and spinal cord membranes, potentially causing photophobia, but less commonly the other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the brain often caused by an infection, which might present with photophobia among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition characterized by intense headaches often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A subtype of migraine that involves visual disturbances (scotoma) and other neurological symptoms before the headache begins.

diagnoses.name: Tension-Type Headache
diagnoses.description: A common type of headache characterized by a constant ache or pressure around the head, especially at the temples or back of the head and neck.

diagnoses.name: Cluster Headache
diagnoses.description: A condition that causes intense headaches on one side of the head, often around the eye, and can be accompanied by eye watering, nasal congestion, or swelling around the eye.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, it's a brief period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke, such as weakness on one side of the body, but typically lasts less than an hour without leaving lasting effects.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical condition in which poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death. Symptoms may include headache, weakness on one side of the body, and difficulty speaking or seeing.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease affecting the brain and spinal cord, marked by weakness, numbness, a lack of coordination, and problems with vision, including scotomas.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: An abnormal growth of cells within the brain, which can be benign or malignant. Symptoms may include headaches, weakness, seizures, and changes in personality or memory.

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition in which you lack enough healthy red blood cells to carry adequate oxygen to your body's tissues, potentially causing headaches and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the inner ear that causes episodes in which you feel as if you're spinning (vertigo), have fluctuating hearing loss, ringing in the ear (tinnitus), and sometimes a feeling of fullness or pressure in your ear.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition characterized by intense headaches often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound. Phonophobia (fear of loud sounds) is a common symptom.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the inner ear causing vertigo, hearing loss, tinnitus, and a feeling of pressure deep inside the ear.

diagnoses.name: Acoustic Neuroma
diagnoses.description: A benign tumor on the cranial nerve that leads from the brain to the inner ear and controls balance and hearing. Symptoms may include hearing loss, tinnitus, dizziness, numbness, and headache.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that affects the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). Symptoms are varied and can include numbness, impairment of speech and of muscular coordination, blurred vision, and severe fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain. Symptoms can include headaches, numbness, hearing loss, and other neurological impairments depending on the tumor's location.

diagnoses.name: Temporal Arteritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of blood vessels, called arteries, in and around the scalp. Symptoms include severe headaches, jaw pain, and sometimes vision problems.

diagnoses.name: Labyrinthitis
diagnoses.description: An inner ear infection or inflammation causing dizziness, loss of balance, and temporary hearing loss.

diagnoses.name: Otitis Media
diagnoses.description: An infection of the air-filled space behind the eardrum (the middle ear). While more common in children, it can cause ear pain, temporary hearing loss, and headache in adults.

diagnoses.name: Vestibular Neuritis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the vestibular nerve, a nerve in the ear that helps control balance. This condition can cause sudden, severe vertigo and may cause hearing loss.

diagnoses.name: Mastoiditis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection affecting the mastoid bone behind the ear. It typically results from a middle ear infection and can cause pain, redness, headache, and hearing loss.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death, causing symptoms like weakness and aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Brain tumor
diagnoses.description: An abnormal growth of cells within the brain, which can cause symptoms such as headaches, weakness, and aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Transient ischemic attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, it produces similar symptoms to a stroke (such as aphasia and weakness) but usually lasts only a few minutes and causes no permanent damage.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with aura
diagnoses.description: A type of migraine that can involve neurological symptoms like aphasia or weakness before the onset of headache.

diagnoses.name: Multiple sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. Symptoms can include aphasia, weakness, and headache.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the brain, caused by an infection or an autoimmune response. It can cause headaches, weakness, and problems with speech.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the fluid and membranes surrounding your brain and spinal cord. Symptoms can include headache, fever, weakness, and difficulty speaking.

diagnoses.name: Brain abscess
diagnoses.description: A collection of pus that develops in the brain owing to an infection or trauma. Symptoms can include headache, aphasia, and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A central nervous system disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing periods of unusual behavior, sensations, and sometimes loss of awareness. Speech difficulties and muscle weakness can occur post-seizure.

diagnoses.name: Subarachnoid hemorrhage
diagnoses.description: Bleeding in the space between the brain and the tissue covering the brain. Symptoms can include a sudden, severe headache, muscle weakness, and difficulty speaking.

diagnoses: Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Viral Infections (such as Epstein-Barr Virus or Cytomegalovirus)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS Syndrome)
Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) - Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis
Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) with secondary Sjögren's syndrome
Hepatitis B or C with cryoglobulinemia
Evans syndrome (Autoimmune hemolytic anemia with immune thrombocytopenia)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease characterized by inflammation of various parts of the body. It can manifest with skin rashes, joint pain, kidney involvement, hair loss, and more serious complications such as damage to the heart, lungs, blood, or nervous system.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that may have features of three other connective tissue diseases: systemic lupus erythematosus, scleroderma, and polymyositis. It is associated with high levels of a distinct autoantibody, known as U1-RNP.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and a distinctive skin rash. The condition can affect adults and children, and its cause is unknown.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Sclerosis (Scleroderma)
diagnoses.description: A group of diseases that cause skin and internal organs to harden and tighten. Symptoms and manifestation vary greatly between individuals and can include skin thickening, stiffness, and internal organ dysfunction.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome (APS)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder characterized by the body mistakenly producing antibodies against certain normal proteins in the blood, leading to blood clots, pregnancy complications, stroke, and thrombocytopenia.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA)
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. The immune system mistakenly attacks the body's tissues, causing painful swelling, eroding of the bone, and joint deformity.

diagnoses.name: Cryoglobulinemia
diagnoses.description: A condition associated with abnormal levels of cryoglobulins in the blood, proteins that precipitate or clump together in cold temperatures, leading to blockage of blood vessels and a variety of symptoms including skin ulcers and kidney damage.

diagnoses.name: Idiopathic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP)
diagnoses.description: A disorder that can lead to easy or excessive bruising and bleeding. The bleeding results from unusually low levels of platelets — the cells that help blood clot.

diagnoses.name: Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: Conditions that affect the normal functioning of the kidneys. Proteinuria is a common indicator of kidney damage, especially in the context of systemic diseases.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that affect connective tissues supporting the skin, bones, blood vessels, and many other organs and tissues. Symptoms may include skin hyperelasticity, fragile skin, and abnormal scarring.

diagnoses: Infectious diseases (certain bacterial, viral, or parasitic infections that can mimic systemic autoimmune diseases)
Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) related to glomerulonephritis
Post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation secondary to dermatologic conditions
Postinflammatory Hyperpigmentation (PIH) secondary to skin lesions
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Viral Infections (e.g., HIV, Hepatitis, Epstein-Barr Virus)
Rheumatoid Arthritis with secondary Sjogren's syndrome
Vasculitis (e.g., Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis, Microscopic Polyangiitis)
Hepatitis B and C associated vasculitides
Lupus nephritis (as a complication of SLE)
